td.mt{width:109.7pt;padding:0cm 5.4pt 0cm 5.4pt;}</style><div class="tr-image"><div class="tr-image-components"></div></div><div style="text-align:left;font-size:10pt"><div>RNS Number : 8668R</div>  <div>AVEVA Group PLC</div>  <div>10 November 2021</div>  <div> </div></div>
<div class="mr">
<p class="arp"><span class="arq">AVEVA GROUP PLC</span></p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="arp"><span class="arq">RESULTS FOR THE SIX MONTHS ENDED 30 SEPTEMBER 2021</span></p>
<p class="arr"> </p>
<p class="ars">Solid financial results, integration of OSIsoft on-track</p>
<p class="art"><span class="ark"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="ad">AVEVA Group plc ('AVEVA' or 'the Group') announces its preliminary results for the six months ended 30 September 2021.</span></p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">On 19 March 2021, the Group announced the completion of the acquisition of OSIsoft, LLC (OSIsoft) enhancing AVEVA's ability to accelerate the digital transformation of the industrial world.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">The statutory results<sup>1</sup> are for the combined AVEVA and OSIsoft business in H1 FY22 and for AVEVA only for H1 FY21. To provide a better understanding of the combined comparative trading performance and to improve transparency, non-statutory results are also shown for the combined Group on a pro forma basis<sup>2</sup>.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">We believe that the pro forma results give helpful insight into the performance of the Group and form a basis from which to consider the outlook.</p>
<p class="arv"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arg">Highlights</span></p>
<p class="arx"> </p>
<p class="arx">Combined AVEVA Group on a pro forma basis</p>
<p class="arx"> </p>
<p class="ary"><span class="are">·    </span>On an organic constant currency basis<span><sup>3</sup></span> pro forma revenue for the combined Group grew 9.0% and adjusted EBIT<sup>4</sup> grew 33.9%; while adjust diluted EPS grew 13.3% and included the tax benefit from the OSIsoft acquisition.</p>
<p class="ary"><span class="arc">·     </span><span class="arb">Pro forma constant currency Annualised Recurring Revenue (ARR)<span><sup>5</sup></span> increased 9.2% to £711.4m (H1 FY21: £651.2m). The introduction of Subscription selling at OSIsoft will support growth in ARR going forward.</span></p>
<p class="ary"><span class="are">·    </span>After the impact of FX translation headwinds, pro forma revenue grew by 0.8% to £516.1m (H1 FY21: £512.2m) and pro forma adjusted EBIT grew 20.5% to £125.2m (H1 FY21: £103.9m), representing a margin of 24.3% (H1 FY21: 20.3%).</p>
<p class="ary"><span class="are">·    </span>Integration of the AVEVA and OSIsoft businesses has progressed well and the Board remains excited about the growth opportunities ahead.</p>
<p class="arx"> </p>
<p class="arx">Statutory results</p>
<p class="arx"> </p>
<p class="ary"><span class="are">·     </span>Revenue was £480.9m after the impact of the deferred revenue haircut (H1 FY21: £332.6m), representing an increase of 44.6%, most of which was due to the acquisition of OSIsoft.</p>
<p class="ary"><span class="are">·    </span>Loss from operations was £74.3m (H1 FY21: £23.2m) with the loss being primarily due to the amortisation of intangible assets of £115.8m (H1 FY21: £46.2m).</p>
<p class="ary"><span class="are">·     </span>Interim dividend is being increased 4.8% to 13.0p pence (H1 FY21: 12.4 pence).</p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="arw">Chief Executive Officer, Peter Herweck said:</p>
<p class="arr"> </p>
<p class="arz">"AVEVA achieved a good first half performance, delivering a solid set of results and laying foundations for future growth. The integration of the AVEVA and OSIsoft businesses has progressed well, with both cost and revenue synergies starting to materialise as planned.</p>
<p class="arz"> </p>
<p class="arz">End market conditions started to improve during the period following disruption caused by the Covid crisis. As a result, we are seeing the resumption of structural growth, driven by increased digitalisation and Net Zero projects, across a wide range of industry sectors. We are also observing an increase in activity in the Energy and Marine sectors as energy prices recover and demand for transportation increases.</p>
<p class="arv"> </p>
<p class="arz">We remain confident in the growth outlook and believe that our first half results form a strong foundation for us to build on and to meet our medium-term targets."</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="asa"><span class="arg"> </span></p>

<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="arz"><span class="aqa">Notes</span></p>
<p class="asi"><sup><span class="aqa"> </span></sup></p>
<p class="art"><span><sup><span class="aqa">1 </span></sup></span><span><span class="aqa">Statutory results include the results for the combined AVEVA Group for the 6 months to 30 September 2021 compared to the results of the standalone AVEVA business only for the 6 months to 30 September 2020. EPS in the prior period has been adjusted for a Bonus Factor of 0.8 to reflect the Bonus element of the November 2020 Rights Issue. </span></span></p>
<p class="asi"><sup><span class="apz"> </span></sup></p>
<p class="art"><span><sup><span class="aqa">2</span></sup></span><span><span class="aqa"> Pro forma results include results for both AVEVA and OSIsoft for the 6 months to 30 September 2021 and the 6 months to 30 September 2020. In addition to this, the results have been adjusted to exclude the effect of the deferred revenue haircut under IFRS 3 (Business Combinations), which reduces current year statutory revenue.</span></span></p>
<p class="asi"><sup><span class="aqa"> </span></sup></p>
<p class="art"><span><sup><span class="aqa">3</span></sup></span><span><span class="aqa"> Organic constant currency revenue excludes a currency translation reduction of £40.8 million; and adjusts for the disposals of the Acquis Software, Termis Software and Water Loss Management Software businesses in June 2021 by removing the results of the disposals from each reporting period.</span></span></p>
<p class="asi"><sup><span class="aqa"> </span></sup></p>
<p class="art"><span><sup><span class="aqa">4 </span></sup></span><span><span class="aqa">Adjusted metrics are calculated before amortisation of intangible assets (excluding other software), share-based payments, gain/loss on fair value of forward foreign exchange contracts and exceptional items. Adjusted Earnings Per Share also includes the tax effects of these adjustments.</span></span></p>
<p class="arw"> </p>
<p class="art"><span><sup><span class="aqa">5 </span></sup></span><span><span class="aqa">ARR makes it easier to track recurring revenue progression by annualising revenue associated with Subscription, Cloud and Maintenance contracts​. It removes distortions caused by revenue recognition standards by annualising the revenue associated with contracts at a point in time. It is calculated on a constant currency basis.</span></span></p>
<p class="arw"> </p>

<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="asa"><span class="apy">Chief Executive's review</span></p>
<p class="asj"><span class="apx"> </span></p>
<p class="asj"><span class="apx">Summary</span></p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="art">AVEVA had a solid first half of the financial year. The Group delivered a good financial performance and made significant operational progress in integrating OSIsoft, which was acquired just before the start of the period.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">On a statutory basis, revenue for the period was £480.9</span><span class="arb"> </span><span class="arb">million which was 44.6% higher compared with the previous year (H1 FY21: £</span><span class="arb">332.6 </span><span class="arb">million). This change was due to the inclusion of OSIsoft in H1 FY21 and growth in the business, partly offset by negative FX translation due to the relative strengthening of Sterling, particularly in relation to the US Dollar.</span></p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">Pro forma organic constant currency revenue grew by 9.0% and proforma adjusted EBIT increased 33.9% on the same basis. The revenue growth was driven by both the heritage AVEVA business, which increased revenue by 5.8% on an organic constant currency basis and the heritage OSIsoft business, which grew revenue by 14.9% on the same basis. The increase in adjusted EBIT was a result of the revenue growth and a slower increase in overall costs, which resulted in positive margin leverage.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">On a reported pro forma basis (i.e. not adjusted for currency translation), Group revenue grew by 0.8% to £516.1 million (H1 FY21: £512.2 million). On the same basis, adjusted EBIT grew by 20.5% to £125.2 million (H1 FY21: £103.9 million). This reduction versus organic constant currency growth was largely due to the relative strength of the Group's reporting currency Sterling, versus the US Dollar, given that the majority of AVEVA's sales are made in US Dollars.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="arx">Integration</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="ask"><span class="apv">The integration of OSIsoft progressed well, in accordance with AVEVA's plans. The organisational model has been established and leadership roles determined. </span></p>
<p class="ask"><span class="apv"> </span></p>
<p class="art">AVEVA is on-track to achieve both cost and revenue synergies in-line with its acquisition model. Pre-tax cash cost synergies are expected of not less than $30 million per annum on a run rate basis by the year ending 31 March 2023. Revenue synergies of at least $100 million per annum are expected by the year ending 31 March 2026.</p>
<p class="ask"><span class="apv"> </span></p>
<p class="ask"><span class="apv">Progress toward achieving cost synergies includes the establishment of plans for removing duplication in office facilities, marketing, and IT. All of the cost synergies have been sized and have target delivery dates established. It is expected that most of the office duplication will be removed by the end of the current financial year.</span></p>
<p class="ask"><span class="apv"> </span></p>
<p class="art">Work towards achieving revenue synergies is also well established. The sales operating model has been determined and incentives have been put in place to drive product portfolio cross selling. The first cross sell synergy contracts have been closed through the direct sales force, the AVEVA partner channel and Schneider Electric.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="ark"> </span></p>
<p class="art">The R&D organisation has been integrated and has accelerated work on the product portfolio roadmap to achieve interoperability between products to add greater value to customers. Good progress has been made, for example in integrating Data Hub and AVEVA Connect. Other major product integrations are underway, including integrating AVEVA Unified Operation Centre and AVEVA Advance Analytics with the PI System and will be launched in calendar year 2022.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="arx">Subscription transition</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">AVEVA also made good progress with its Subscription transition. The heritage AVEVA business achieved 16.2% growth in on-premise Subscription revenue and 29.2% growth in SaaS revenue on a constant currency basis. The heritage OSIsoft business did not have a material Subscription or SaaS offering during the first half, although these have now been introduced and are expected to support future growth in ARR.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">AVEVA made significant progress in developing its Cloud business. Key products were launched on the Group's SaaS platform, AVEVA Connect. These included Unified Engineering, Unified Operations Control and Unified Supply Chain.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">While absolute revenue from SaaS <span class="arb">products was relatively small due to a low starting base, order wins by contract value wer</span>e more than double revenue. Sales of Engineering products drove growth in the first half. This is expected to continue, while being increasingly augmented by sales of Operations products as customers choose to move towards a hybrid Cloud deployment model.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">AVEVA won a substantial number of new logos during the first half including Kairos Power and <span class="asl">T</span><span class="kr"><span class="apt">é</span><span class="apu">cnicas Reunidas</span></span>.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art">In the context of having not yet launched a Subscription offering, the growth that OSIsoft achieved did not make a full contribution to growth in ARR for the Group during the first half. Notwithstanding this, period end ARR for the combined AVEVA Group was £711.4 million (30 September 2020: £651.2 million). This represented a 12 month increase of 9.2% on a pro forma constant currency basis. This growth was driven by the heritage AVEVA business, which increased ARR by 10.5%, while OSIsoft increased ARR by 6.8%.</p>
<p class="art"><span> </span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="aps">Pro forma regional performance</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art">AVEVA is managed on a regional basis.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span style="font-weight:bold">EMEA</span> revenue was £172.2 million, representing a decrease of 3.6% (H1 FY21: £178.6 million) due to the impact of FX translation. On an organic constant currency basis, sales grew 3.5%. AVEVA achieved good growth in Eastern Europe and the Middle East in particular. On a product basis, Engineering, Asset Performance and Data Management achieved good growth.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span style="font-weight:bold">Americas</span> revenue grew by 1.8% to £225.3 million (H1 FY21: £221.3 million) due to the impact of FX translation. On an organic constant currency basis, sales grew 10.6%. The growth was broad based with all regions delivering a good performance. All business areas showed a year-on-year improvement, with growth being led by Monitoring & Control and Information Management.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span style="font-weight:bold">Asia Pacific</span> revenue was £118.6 million, representing an increase of 5.6% (H1 FY21: £112.3 million). On an organic constant currency basis, sales increased 14.5% with growth being led by a recovery in China. On a product basis, Planning & Operations, Monitoring & Control and Data Management achieved good growth.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="apr">Business units</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Following the acquisition of OSIsoft, AVEVA has been organised into two business units: Engineering and Operations. </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span style="font-weight:bold"><span class="arb">Engineering</span></span><span class="arb"> consists of Engineering and Simulation software. In turn, Engineering software includes Engineering & Design, Project Execution and Engineering Information Management. Simulation includes Simulation & Learning and Value Chain Optimisation.</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">Engineering contributed 29.9% of pro forma revenue in the period. On an organic constant currency basis, revenue increased by 6.2%</span><span class="apq">.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">AVEVA saw </span>good demand for E<span>ngineering Information Management, Simulation & Learning and Value Chain Optimisation in particular.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span>End market conditions started to improve during the period following disruption caused by the Covid crisis. AVEVA's Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) customers began to recover as both Net Zero projects and an improving general pipeline of greenfield asset construction projects started to build.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span>AVEVA's </span>Owner Operator customers continued to drive their digital twin strategies, deploying the Engineering Information Management portfolio, with new customer wins at PTT and a leading semiconductor chip manufacturer.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">Owner Operators also continued to drive carbon emission reduction programs across their integrated assets with our Value Chain Optimization portfolio, with new customer wins at Indian Oil and LyondellBasell.</p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="art">In terms of end markets, there was an increase in orders from the Oil & Gas and Marine sector as energy prices recovered and demand for transportation increased. For example, AVEVA saw order wins with International Maritime Industries and Sinopec Engineering.  Demand from the Chemicals market also grew as customers drove their circular economy agendas. Key wins came from Dupont and Beijing Petro Chemicals.</p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span style="font-weight:bold"><span class="arb">Operations</span></span><span class="arb"> consists of Asset Performance, Monitoring & Control and Information Management. In turn, Asset Performance consists of Asset Performance Management and Manufacturing Executions Systems software. Monitoring & Control includes HMI SCADA, Enterprise Visualisation and Pipeline Management software. Information Management consists of the recently acquired OSIsoft business.</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">Operations contributed 70.1% of pro forma revenue in the period. On an organic constant currency basis, revenue increased 10.2</span><span class="apq">%.</span></p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="aru"><span>End market conditions improved versus the previous financial year, allowing for the resumption of structural growth driven by increased digitalisation across a wide range of industry sectors, with notable wins in Power, Mining, Consumer Packaged Goods and Energy.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span>Asset Performance Management delivered a strong performance, with growth in Energy and Utilities. For example, the Group achieved a recent large order win in Asset Performance Management with Saudi Aramco.</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span>Monitoring & Control delivered good growth, while continuing the transition to a Subscription-based recuring revenue model. Again, AVEVA saw good wins in the Energy and Infrastructure sectors.</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span>In Information Management, the OSIsoft business performed strongly and continued to win significant new business, for example in the Mining market with Vale.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="aps">Outlook </span></p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">The Board remains confident in the outlook for AVEVA. Growth is expected to continue in the second half of the financial year on an organic constant currency basis, supported by a good contract pipeline and improving market conditions as economies recover from the Covid crisis.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">Growth in AVEVA's ARR is expected to increase as Subscription offers are introduced for products from the acquired OSIsoft business and the proportion of SaaS sales rises.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="app">Finance review</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="apo">Overview</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">On 25 August 2020, AVEVA announced that it had reached agreement to acquire OSIsoft at an enterprise value of $5.0 billion</span><span class="arb">. The transaction subsequently completed on 19 March 2021 and therefore the statutory results compare the performance of the combined AVEVA and OSIsoft business in H1 FY22 with the standalone AVEVA business in H1 FY21.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">The finance review begins with a commentary of those statutory results and then covers pro forma results to show the underlying performance of the combined business.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="apr">Statutory results</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">On a statutory basis, revenue for the period was £480.9</span><span class="arb"> </span><span class="arb">million which was 44.6% higher compared with the previous year (H1 FY21: £</span><span class="arb">332.6 </span><span class="arb">million). This change was due to the inclusion of OSIsoft in H1 FY21 and growth in the business, partly offset by negative FX translation due to the relative strengthening of Sterling, particularly in relation to the Dollar.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">Subscription revenue, which includes rental contracts and Cloud contracts, grew 17.7% to £134.1 million (H1 FY21: £113.9 million), primarily due to the growth in the heritage AVEVA business.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">Maintenance revenue grew by 63.4% to £162.7 million (H1 FY21: £99.6 million), primarily due to the </span><span class="arb">inclusion of OSIsoft in H1 FY21.</span></p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="aru">Perpetual licences grew 106.8% to £127.6 million (H1 FY21: £61.7 million), primarily due to the inclusion of OSIsoft in H1 FY21 and growth in the OSIsoft business.</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="aru">Services revenue declined 1.6% to £56.5 million (H1 FY21: £57.4 million) due to a focus on higher margin software revenue.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Total statutory costs increased to </span>£555.2 million (H1 FY21: £355.8 million). This increase was due to the acquisition of OSIsoft and the cost of sale, operating cost and <span class="asm">amortisation of intangible assets associated with this.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">The Group made a loss before tax of </span><span class="arb">£80.3 million </span><span class="arb">(H1 FY21: </span><span class="arb">£24.2</span><span class="arb"> million). This was due </span><span class="asn">to the amortisation of intangible assets relating to AVEVA's combinations with the Schneider Electric industrial software business and OSIsoft.</span><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art">Basic loss per s<span class="arb">hare was (27.07)p (H1 FY21: (10.11)p and diluted earnings per share were (27.07)p (H1 FY21: (10.11)p).</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">The statutory tax charge was £1.2 million (H1 FY21: credit of £3.9 million).</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Dividends</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">An interim dividend of 13.0 pence will be payable on 4 February 2022 to shareholders on the register on 7 January 2022. This represents an increase of 4.8% versus the prior year interim dividend (H1 FY21: 12.4 pence).</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="apo">Operating cash flow</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Cash generated from operating activities before tax was £(14.4) million, compared to £23.7 million generated in the previous year.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">This negative amount was due to cash paid in the period in relation to the acquisition of OSIsoft of £65.5 million and other exceptional items of £17.8 million (H1 FY21: £31.1 million).</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">In addition to this, first half cash flow is impacted by the payment of bonus and sales commissions from the previous financial year, which in H1 FY22 included those related to OSIsoft.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Balance sheet</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">On 30 September 2021, AVEVA had net debt of £533.6</span><span class="apl"> </span><span class="arb">million (31 March 2021: £367.9 million). This reflects the $900 million term loan taken out to part finance the acquisition of OSIsoft, together with cash and treasury deposits of £136.6 million (31 March 2021: £286.9 million). The change in cash and treasury deposits mainly reflects £65.5 million paid in relation to the OSIsoft acquisition since the year end and dividend payments of £70.8 million. The remainder of the change in net debt in Sterling terms relates to currency translation.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Non-current assets </span>were £5.7 billion (31 March 2021: £5.8 billion), reflecting goodwill and intangible assets that arose from the combination with the Schneider <span class="arb">Electric industrial software business and the OSIsoft acquisition. Goodwill and intangible assets were £5.5 billion (31 March 2021: £5.6 billion).</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">Trade and other receivables were £266.5 million (31 March 2021: £317.0 million). Contract assets increased to £241.2 million from £215.6 million at 31 March 2021. This increase included the impact of new contract wins and a release of a forward-looking provision held against contract assets.</span></p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art">Contract liabilities were £232.5 million (31 March 2021: £239.7 million), reflecting a higher billing profile in the second half.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>

<p class="arx"><span class="apr"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Pro forma revenue</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>

<p class="arx"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Subscription revenue grew by 8.6% to £</span><span class="arb">134.3 </span><span class="arb">million (H1 FY21: £123.7 million). On an organic constant currency basis the increase was 15.2%. This was driven by growth in sales of Subscription revenue within the heritage AVEVA business as the transition to a recuring revenue model continued.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Maintenance revenue declined by 5.7% to £197.5</span><span class="arb"> </span><span class="arb">million (H1 FY21: £209.5 million). On an organic constant currency basis there was an increase of 2.5%. This was driven by growth in Maintenance revenue associated with the growth of the OSIsoft business, which more than offset a decline in Maintenance revenue at the heritage AVEVA business due to the planned Subscription transition.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Perpetual licence revenue grew by 6.7% to £127.8</span><span class="arb"> </span><span class="arb">million (H1 FY21: £119.8 million). On an organic constant currency basis the increase was 17.6%. This was driven by strong growth from the heritage OSIsoft business, which had not yet moved to a Subscription offering in the first half.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Services revenue declined by 4.6% to £56.5million (H1 FY21: £59.2 million). On an organic constant currency basis the increase was 1.5%. This was driven by growth in the overall business, partly offset by a focus on higher margin software revenue.</span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="arb">Pro forma costs</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="apo"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb">An analysis of total expenses is summarised below. Overall, operating costs were a little behind AVEVA's plan, largely due to a tight labour market causing some delay in new hires.</span></p>

<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span style="font-weight:bold"><span class="arb">Cost of sales</span></span><span class="arb"> decreased by 3.3% to £106.6 million (H1 FY21: £110.2 million). This decrease was due to FX translation. On a constant currency basis the increase was 3.1%. This was largely due to higher SaaS hosting costs.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span style="font-weight:bold"><span class="arb">Research & Development costs</span></span><span class="arb"> were £80.9 million (H1 FY21: £ 89.3 million), representing a decrease of 9.4%. On a constant currency basis the decrease was 3.0%. This was due a slight increase in employment costs more than offset by reductions in consultancy, IT costs and some delayed recruiting.</span></p>
<p class="asx"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span style="font-weight:bold"><span class="arb">Selling and distribution expenses</span></span><span class="arb"> were £123.1 million (H1 FY21: £130.1 million), representing a decrease of 5.4%. On a constant currency basis the increase was 0.9%. </span>The relatively flat costs represented inflation and higher run-rate costs entering the year offset by some savings on the timing of backfilling open positions.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="art"><span style="font-weight:bold"><span class="arb">Administrative expenses</span></span><span class="arb"> were £84.4 million (H1 FY21: £</span>77.8 million), representing a increase of 8.5%. On a constant currency basis the increase was 17.9%. This was driven by higher costs in IT, finance and HR, due to increases in capacity being needed as the business scales.</p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="asx"><span style="font-weight:bold"><span class="arb">Net impairment loss from financial assets</span></span><span class="arb"> represents the impairment of accounts receivable and contract assets. During the period there was a credit following a review of forward-looking provisions against contract assets. This reversal of provisions led to a positive figure of £4.1 million (FY20: negative £0.9 million).</span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="ari"> </span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="arb">Pro forma adjusted EBIT</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="apo"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Adjusted EBIT increased by 20.5% to £125.2 million (H1 FY21: £103.9</span><span class="arb"> </span><span class="arb">million). This resulted in an adjusted EBIT margin of 24.3</span><span class="arb">% (H1 FY21: 20.3%).</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Pro forma net interest charge</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">The combined pro forma interest charge assumes that the $900 million term loan was drawn down on 1 April 2020 and therefore a full year's interest is charged in each period. Total net interest was £6.0 million (H1 FY21: £9.3 million). </span>The year-on-year reduction was largely due to lower LIBOR rates.</p>
<p class="asy"><span class="amr"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Pro forma taxation</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">The pro forma tax charge on adjusted profit before tax was £6.0 million (H1 FY21: credit of £5.1 million), which equates to an effective tax rate of 5.0% (H1 FY21: 5.4% credit). This tax charge factors in the benefit of UK and US tax incentives on intellectual property and the tax step-up relating to the acquisition of OSIsoft. Although the first half tax rate percentage is lower than the expected full year rate because while the tax deduction relating to the acquisition of OSIsoft accrues evenly over time, first half profits are typically lower than second half profits; we expect these factors to continue to benefit AVEVA's  tax rate. On a full year basis, the expected tax rate on adjusted profit before tax is expected to be less than 10%.</span></p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="asj"><span class="arb">Pro forma earnings per share</span></p>
<p class="asz"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Pro forma diluted adjusted EPS increased by 13.3% to 37.38 pence (H1 FY21: 32.98</span><span class="amp"> </span><span class="arb">pence) as a result of the higher adjusted EBIT and a tax credit in the prior year.</span></p>
<p class="arx"><span class="arb"> </span></p>

<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>

<p class="art"><span class="arb">Acquisition and integration activities primarily related to consultancy fees paid to advisers and the costs of additional temporary resources due to the combination with OSIsoft, together with IT and systems integration.</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb">Other expense relates to capital expenditure reimbursements from Schneider Electric in H1 FY21 and in H1 FY22, impairment relating to the decision to retire AVEVA steel fabrication software and a loss on the sale of assets (see Note 8 for further details).</span></p>
<p class="art"><span class="arb"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="asn">Amortisation relates to the amortisation of the fair valued heritage AVEVA intangible assets under acquisition accounting, following the combination with the Schneider Electric industrial software business and the amortisation of intangibles relating to the OSIsoft acquisition. </span><span class="ata">Of the £115.7m amortisation charge, £72.7m relates to the intangibles acquired through the OSIsoft acquisition. </span></p>

<p class="arw"><span class="amc">Independent Review Report to AVEVA Group plc</span></p>
<p class="atb"> </p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Conclusion</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="atc">We have been engaged by the Company to review the condensed set of financial statements in the half-yearly financial report for the six months ended 30 September 2021 which comprises the Consolidated Income Statement, the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income, the Consolidated Balance Sheet, the Consolidated Statement of Changes in Shareholders' Equity, the Consolidated Cash Flow Statement and the related notes 1 to 17. We have read the other information contained in the half yearly financial report and considered whether it contains any apparent misstatements or material inconsistencies with the information in the condensed set of financial statements. </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="atc"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="atc">Based on our review, nothing has come to our attention that causes us to believe that the condensed set of financial statements in the half-yearly financial report for the six months ended 30 September 2021 is not prepared, in all material respects, in accordance with UK adopted International Accounting Standard 34 and the Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules of the United Kingdom's Financial Conduct Authority.</span></p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Basis for conclusion </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="atd">We conducted our review in accordance with International Standard on Review Engagements 2410 (UK and Ireland) 'Review of Interim Financial Information Performed by the Independent Auditor of the Entity' issued by the Auditing Practices Board.  A review of interim financial information consists of making enquiries, primarily of persons responsible for financial and accounting matters, and applying analytical and other review procedures. A review is substantially less in scope than an audit conducted in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (UK) and consequently does not enable us to obtain assurance that we would become aware of all significant matters that might be identified in an audit. Accordingly, we do not express an audit opinion.</span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="atd"> </span></p>
<p class="aru"><span class="atd">As disclosed in note 2, the annual financial statements of the Group will be prepared in accordance with UK adopted international accounting standards. The condensed set of financial statements included in this half-yearly financial report has been prepared in accordance with UK adopted International Accounting Standard 34, 'Interim Financial Reporting'.</span></p>
<p class="ate"><span class="alz"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Responsibilities of the directors</span></p>
<p class="ate"><span class="alz">The directors are responsible for preparing the half-yearly financial report in accordance with the Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules of the United Kingdom's Financial Conduct Authority.</span></p>
<p class="ate"><span class="alz"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Auditor's responsibilities for the review of the financial information</span></p>
<p class="ate"><span class="alz">In reviewing the half-yearly report, we are responsible for expressing to the Company a conclusion on the condensed set of financial statements in the half-yearly financial report. Our conclusion is based on procedures that are less extensive than audit procedures, as described in the Basis for Conclusion paragraph of this report.</span></p>
<p class="atf"><span class="alx"> </span></p>
<p class="arw"><span class="arb">Use of our report</span></p>

<p class="a"> </p>
<p class="asa"><span class="amc">Notes to the Interim Report</span></p>
<p class="atb"> </p>
<p class="atv">1    The Interim Report</p>
<p class="atw"><span class="atx">The Interim Report was approved by the Board on 9 November 2021. The interim condensed financial statements set out in the Interim Report</span><span class="aty"> are unaudited but have been reviewed by the auditor, Ernst & Young LLP, and their report to the Company is set</span><span class="aet"> out above. </span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alx"> </span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alx"> </span></p>
<p class="atz">2    Basis of preparation and accounting policies</p>
<p class="aua">a)   Basis of preparation</p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alz">This Interim Report has been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 'Interim Financial Reporting'</span><span class="aer"> </span><span class="aet">as issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and as adopted by the UK, and the disclosure requirements of the Listing Rules.</span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alz"> </span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alz">The Interim Report does not include all the information and disclosures required in the annual financial statements and should be read in conjunction with the Annual Report for the year ended 31 March 2021.</span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alz"> </span></p>
<p class="aru">The financial information set out within this report does not constitute AVEVA's consolidated statutory financial statements as defined in Section 434 of the Companies Act 2006. The results for the year ended 31 March 2021 <span class="aub">have been extracted from the consolidated statutory financial statements for AVEVA Group plc for the year ended </span><span class="atd">31 March 2021 on which the auditor</span> gave an unqualified report (which made no statement under Section 498(2) or 498(3) respectively of the Companies Act 2006 and did not draw attention to any matters by way of emphasis) and have been filed with the Registrar of Companies.</p>
<p class="art"> </p>
<p class="atv">b)   Accounting policies</p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alz">Except for the application of UK-adopted international accounting standards, for which there are no material differences from International Financial Reporting Standards as issued by the IASB and adopted by the EU when applied to AVEVA, the Interim Report has been prepared on the basis of the accounting policies set out in the most recently published Annual Report of the Group for the year ended 31 March 2021. New standards and amendments effective from 1 April 2021 have not had an impact on the interim consolidated financial statements of the Group.</span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alx"> </span></p>
<p class="atv">c)   Non-GAAP measures</p>
<p class="atw"><span class="alz">The Group presents the non-GAAP performance measure 'adjusted earnings before interest and tax (EBIT)' on the face of the Consolidated Income Statement and reconciles this to profit from operations as required to be presented under the applicable accounting standards. Adjusted EBIT is not defined by IFRSs and therefore may not be directly comparable with the adjusted EBIT measures of other companies. It is not intended to be a substitute for, or superior to, GAAP measures of profit. The Directors believe that this alternative measure of profit provides a reliable and consistent measure of the Group's underlying performance. Adjusted earnings per share is calculated having adjusted profit after tax for the same items, their tax effect, the deferred revenue haircut arising due to the fair valuing of OSIsoft's contract liabilities on acquisition, and the tax effect of the deferred revenue haircut.</span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="auc"> </span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="auc">The business is managed and measured on a day-to-day basis using adjusted results. To arrive at adjusted results, certain adjustments are made for normalised and exceptional items that are individually important and which could, if included, distort the understanding of the performance for the year and the comparability between periods.</span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="auc"> </span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="auc">The Group also presents pro forma results within the Chief Executive's Review and Finance Review. For the six months ended 30 September 2021, these represent the Group's adjusted results with an additional adjustment to add back the deferred revenue haircut arising due to the fair valuing of OSIsoft's contract liabilities on acquisition. For the six months ended 30 September 2020, these include pre-acquisition OSIsoft results for the period, assumes no synergies or trading between the groups, and assumes the term loan used to finance the acquisition was entered into on 1 April 2020. These are presented to increase year-on-year comparability, given the significant impact of the OSIsoft acquisition upon the newly enlarged Group's results.</span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="auc"> </span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="auc">Additional information, definitions and reconciliations from GAAP measures are provided in the non-GAAP measures section below. </span></p>
<p class="atw"><span class="aud"> </span></p>
<p class="aue"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="atv">3    Going concern</p>
<p class="aru">In adopting the going concern basis for preparing the interim financial statements, the Group has considered the business activities, and principal risks and uncertainties in the context of the current operating environment. This includes expectations of business performance and estimated potential ongoing impact of global Covid-19 pandemic and its subsequent impact upon the Group's cashflow, liquidity headroom and covenant forecasts.</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="aru">At 30 September 2021, the Group held external debt in the form of a £669.5 million term loan, due for repayment in March 2024. The Group has access to a £250.0 million Revolving Credit Facility (RCF), of which nil was drawn down at 30 September 2021. This facility is due for renewal in February 2024, with two one-year extension options subject to the lender's approval.</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="asz">The Group has developed working capital financial models covering the period from the signing of this Interim Report to 31 December 2022. These include:</p>
<p class="auf"><span class="are">·      </span><span style="font-weight:bold">Scenario 1</span>: A base case scenario, representing the Group's forecasts for the period.</p>
<p class="aug"><span class="are">·      </span><span style="font-weight:bold">Scenario 2</span>: A stress case scenario, representing a severe but plausible downside where revenue is decreased 10% from the base case and there are moderate delays in cash collection (a 10-day increase in debtor days).</p>
<p class="auh"><span class="are">·      </span><span style="font-weight:bold">Scenario 3</span>: A more severe stress case where revenue is decreased 20% from the base case and there are severe delays in cash collection (a 20-day increase in debtor days).</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="asz">Under Scenarios 1 and 2, there is no expected requirement to draw down on the RCF across the going concern period. Under Scenario 3, the Group would utilise the RCF, but within the current liquidity levels available. Throughout all scenarios, the Group has liquidity headroom on existing facilities and against the RCF financial covenants during the assessment period. Should a more extreme downside scenario occur, additional mitigating actions could be taken such as the cancellation or deferral of dividend payments and reductions in other discretionary operating costs.</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="aru">The interim financial statements for the six months ended 30 September 2021 have therefore been prepared under the going concern basis of accounting.</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="atv">4    Risks and uncertainties</p>
<p class="aui"><span class="aet">There are several potential risks and uncertainties which could have a material impact on the Group's long-term performance. The principal risks and uncertainties as set out in the Annual Report for the year ended 31 March 2021 remain unchanged, except for Industrial digitalisation strategy which is no longer considered a principal risk. The unchanged risks are:</span></p>
<p class="aui"><span class="aet"> </span></p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Talent;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Subscription;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Cloud;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Sustainability;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>OSIsoft integration;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Competitors;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Dependency on cyclical markets;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>AVEVA software products implicated in industrial accidents or customer cyber attack;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Cyber attack;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Regulatory compliance;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Global economic disruption and declining GDPs;</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Internal IT systems (suitability and continuity); and</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Disruptive technologies.</p>
<p class="aui"><span class="aet"> </span></p>
<p class="aui"><span class="aet">Industrial digitalisation strategy is no longer considered to be a principal risk because:</span></p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>The market has evolved; the move towards digitalisation has accelerated within the last 24 months where customers have understood and accepted the imperative need to evolve. There is now a diminished need to convince customers to digitalise, rather it is the expected standard.</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>Given this market evolution and AVEVA's strategic acquisition of OSIsoft, which further consolidates its position within the industrial digitalisation market, this is no longer a material threat to AVEVA over the next 18 months.</p>
<p class="auj"><span class="aem">·      </span>AVEVA's strategy to grow its market share of industrial digitalisation now morphs into other existing principal risks, namely strategic risk elements of Cloud, Competitors, Sustainability, Subscription and OSIsoft integration.</p>
<p class="aui"><span class="aet"> </span></p>
<p class="aui"><span class="aty">These risks are described in more detail on pages </span><span class="alz">36 to 46<span class="aub"> of the 2021 Annual Report. The Directors routinely </span>monitor these risks and uncertainties, and appropriate actions are taken to manage them within agreed risk appetites<span class="auk">. Included in the Chief Executive's Review is a commentary on the outlook of the Group for the remaining six months </span>of the year.</span></p>
<p class="aui"><span class="aet"> </span></p>
<p class="aul"><span class="aek">At an executive level, risk management remains the responsibility of the Executive Risk Committee, who report to the Board on risk matters.</span></p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="u"> </p>

<p class="atv">6    Segment information</p>
<p class="aul"><span class="aek">The Executive Leadership Team (ELT) monitors and appraises the business based on the performance of three geographic regions: Americas; Asia Pacific; and Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA). These three regions are the basis of the Group's primary operating segments reported in the financial statements. Performance is evaluated based on regional contribution using the same accounting policies as adopted for the Group's financial statements. There is no inter-segment revenue. Corporate costs include centralised functions such as Executive Management, Information Management, Finance and Legal. Balance sheet information is not included in the information provided to the ELT. </span></p>

<p class="bc"> </p>
<p class="ave"><span class="aer">The total cash outflow during the year as a result of exceptional items was £35.1 million (H1 FY21: £31.1 million).</span></p>
<p class="ave"><span class="aer"> </span></p>
<p class="atv">a)   Acquisition costs</p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zh">Current and prior year acquisition costs relate to adviser fees incurred as a result of the acquisition of OSIsoft, LLC which completed on 19 March 2021. These costs are not expected to significantly increase in the second half of the financial year.</span></p>
<p class="bc"><span> </span></p>
<p class="avf">b)   Integration and restructuring</p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer">Integration and restructuring included £7.8 million in relation to the integration of OSIsoft, LLC, consisting primarily of consultancy fees paid to advisers and the costs of additional temporary resources. Costs of £8.0 million were incurred in relation to the integration of heritage AVEVA and Schneider Electric industrial software business, relating primarily to the implementation of a global ERP system. </span></p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer"> </span></p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer">Prior year integration and restructuring related to the integration of heritage AVEVA and the Schneider Electric industrial software business. Key activities included work undertaken to exit the Transitional Service Agreements (TSA) provided by Schneider Electric; costs incurred in the initial design and build phases of the new ERP system; and assistance from consultants to the Group in running programmes designed to deliver revenue and cost synergies. </span></p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer"> </span></p>
<p class="atv">c)   Other expense/(income)</p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer">Other expense includes a £2.8 million loss on sale resulting from the disposal of the Acquis Software, Termis Software and Water Loss Management Software business. See note 12(b) for further details. £14.9 million relates to an impairment of intangible assets (developed technology and customer relationships) associated with the Group's steel fabrication business, following the announcement in July 2021 of these products' retirement. These assets are allocated across all operating segments. A discounted cash flow model was used to determine the value in use over the remaining life.</span></p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer"> </span></p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer">Prior year other income related to the reimbursement from Schneider Electric for capital expenditure incurred as part of the Group's migration activities covered by Transitional Services Agreements (TSA) following the combination of heritage AVEVA and SES in February 2018.</span></p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer"> </span></p>
<p class="atv">d)   Tax impact</p>
<p class="avg"><span class="aer">The tax credit on the exceptional items of </span><span class="aer">£34.2 million </span><span class="aer">(H1 FY21: £29.0 million) is </span><span class="aer">£5.9 million </span><span class="aer">(H1 FY21: £4.2 million).</span></p>
<p class="bc"> </p>
<p class="ave"> </p>
<p class="atv">9    Income tax expense</p>
<p class="aru">The total tax expense for the half year ended 30 September 2021 is £1.2 million (H1 FY21: credit of £3.9 million).</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="aru">The effective tax rate on the loss before tax is (1.5)% (H1 FY21: 16.1%). The difference between the Group's effective tax rate and the US tax rate of 24.0% is due to a £17.0 million expense relating to the increase in the UK tax rate to 25% from 1 April 2023 and higher overseas tax rates.</p>
<p class="aru"> </p>
<p class="aru">The tax credit on adjusted profit before tax is £3.2 million (H1 FY21: expense of £9.5 million) which equates to an effective tax rate of (3.8)% (H1 FY21: 17.2%).</p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zf"> </span></p>
<p class="u"> </p>
<p class="atv">10   Ordinary dividends</p>
<p class="avh"><span class="ze">The proposed interim dividend of 13.0 pence per ordinary share will be payable on 4 February 2022 to shareholders on the register on 7 January 2022. In accordance with IFRS, no provision for the interim dividend has been made in these financial statements. </span></p>
<p class="avh"><span class="ze"> </span></p>
<p class="avh"><span class="ze">The dividends relating to year ended 31 March 2021 were declared and paid relating to AVEVA Group plc.</span></p>

<p class="avo"><span class="akv">1.     Basic and adjusted EPS for September 2020 has been restated and adjusted for a bonus factor of 0.80 to reflect the bonus element of the November 2020 rights issue. <p class="auz"> </p>
<p class="avf">b)   Disposal of Acquis Software, Termis Software and Water Loss Management Software businesses</p>
<p class="asx">On 11 May 2021 the Group entered into an agreement whereby it agreed to sell the business and assets of Acquis Software, Termis Software and Water Loss Management Software to Schneider Electric for an aggregate consideration of £1.6 million. This transaction was made at arm's length, with the consideration set based upon independent advice.</p>
<p class="asx"> </p>
<p class="asx">This completed on 30 June 2021. A loss on disposal of £2.8 million was recognised, calculated as follows:</p>

<p class="avy"><span style="font-weight:bold">15  </span> <span style="font-weight:bold">Capital reduction</span></p>
<p class="a">The Group received approval from shareholders to perform a £1.0 billion capital reduction at the Annual General Meeting on 7 July 2021. This completed on 10 August 2021, resulting in a reduction in share premium and an increase in reserves within retained earnings.</p>

<p class="asz"><span>The Group provides a number of guarantees for obligations to complete and deliver projects. These include bid, performance and warranty bonds, and guarantees against advance payments, all of which arise in the ordinary course of business and are issued by either banking partners or AVEVA parent companies. The amounts disclosed above represent the Group's contractual exposure at the balance sheet date.</span></p>
<p class="avq"> </p>
<p class="avq"> </p>
<p class="avq"> </p>
<p class="asa"><span class="amc">Non-GAAP Measures (unaudited)</span></p>
<p class="a"> </p>
<p class="aru">Various non-GAAP measures are presented throughout this Interim Report, which management believe provide useful information for understanding the Group's financial performance. These non-GAAP measures should be considered in addition to IFRS measures and are not intended to be a substitute for them.</p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zh">                                                                                                                                    </span></p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zh">The Group's adjusted results exclude the costs relating to major integration or restructuring events while including the benefits. They also exclude significant recurring expense relating to </span><span class="aer">normalised</span><span class="zh"> items. Therefore, adjusted results will present a more </span><span class="aer">favourable</span><span class="zh"> view than GAAP measures and should not be considered to be a complete picture of the Group's financial performance.</span></p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zh"> </span></p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zh">As the Group's non-GAAP measures are not defined by IFRS, they may not be directly comparable with other companies who use similar measures.</span></p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zh"> </span></p>
<p class="ave"><span class="zh">Further information, definitions, the intention in presenting these measures, and a reconciliation from the nearest IFRS measure are provided below.</span></p>
<div class="story-table-container"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="awg" style="width:662">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td class="ug" style="width:99">
<p class="asa"><span class="aqa">Non-GAAP measure </span></p>
</td>
<td class="uf" style="width:61">
<p class="asa"><span class="aqa">Closest equivalent IFRS measure</span></p>
</td>
<td class="ue" style="width:307">
<p class="asa"><span class="aqa">Definition and purpose</span></p>
</td>
<td class="ud" style="width:137">
<p class="asa"><span class="aqa">Reconciliation / calculation</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="uc" colspan="4" style="width:647">
<p class="asa"><span class="aqa"> Income statement - revenue measures</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Annualised recurring revenue (ARR)</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">The non-cancellable contract consideration related to subscription and maintenance contracts as at the reporting date divided by the number of days in the non-cancellable contract period and multiplied by 365.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">ARR represents the annualised value of the recurring revenue base that is expected to be carried into future periods.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">ARR is calculated on a constant currency basis.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">ARR growth is a component of the Group bonus scheme.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Consistent with definition given. </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">This cannot be reconciled to an IFRS measure.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Revenue at constant currency</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Revenue</span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Constant currency is derived by translating the relevant current year figure at prior year average exchange rates.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Constant currency enables measurement of performance on a comparable year-on-year basis without the potentially distorting effect of foreign exchange translation.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">See section a below.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Organic revenue at constant currency</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Revenue</span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Constant currency figures, adjusted for significant one-off events affecting year-on-year comparability, including acquisitions and disposals of subsidiaries.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Organic constant currency enables measurement of performance on a comparable year-on-year basis without the potentially distorting effects of foreign exchange movements and merger & acquisition activity.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">See section a below.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Recurring revenue</span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Recurring revenue is defined as subscription revenue plus maintenance revenue.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Recurring revenue is revenue earned from customers for the provision of goods or services over a contractual term, where future contract renewal is required for ongoing use of the product.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">See section a below.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="uc" colspan="4" style="width:647">
<p class="asa"><span class="aqa"> Income statement - cost measures</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted costs</span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Expense excluding exceptional and normalised items.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted costs allow for the comparison of results year-on-year without the potentially distorting effects of significant one-off items or items which do not relate to the underlying performance of the Group.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">See section c below.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted costs at constant currency</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Constant currency is derived by translating the relevant current year figure at prior year average exchange rates.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Constant currency enables measurement of performance on a comparable year-on-year basis without the potentially distorting effect of foreign exchange movements.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">See section c below.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Exceptional items</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Items which are non-recurring and are identified by virtue of either their size or their nature. These items can include, but are not restricted to:</span></p>
<p class="awh"><span class="tx">·      </span><span class="aqa">costs of significant restructuring exercises;</span></p>
<p class="awi"><span class="tx">·      </span><span class="aqa">fees associated with business combinations; and</span></p>
<p class="awj"><span class="tx">·      </span><span class="aqa">costs incurred in integrating acquired companies.</span></p>
<p class="bc"><span> </span></p>
<p class="bc"><span>In the six months ended 30 September 2021, exceptional items also includes the loss on disposal of a business and impairment of intangible assets following the decision to end-of-life the associated products.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Exceptional items are excluded from statutory measures to determine adjusted results.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Exceptional items are included on the face of the Consolidated Income Statement. Further information on the nature of exceptional items is included within note 8 of the notes to the Interim Report.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Normalised items</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">These are recurring items which management consider to have a distorting effect on the underlying results of the Group. These include:</span></p>
<p class="awh"><span class="tx">·      </span><span class="aqa">amortisation of intangible assets (excluding other software);</span></p>
<p class="awi"><span class="tx">·      </span><span class="aqa">share-based payment charges; and</span></p>
<p class="awj"><span class="tx">·      </span><span class="aqa">fair value adjustments on financial derivatives.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Normalised items are excluded from statutory measures to determine adjusted results.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Normalised items are included on the face of the Consolidated Income Statement. Further information on the rationale for these items being normalised is included in note 2(c) of the notes to the Interim Report.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="uc" colspan="4" style="width:647">
<p class="asa"><span class="aqa"> Income statement - profit measures</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted EBIT</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Profit from operations</span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Earnings before finance revenue, finance expense, tax, exceptional items, and normalised items.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted results allow for the comparison of results year-on-year without the potentially distorting effects of significant one-off items or items which do not relate to the underlying performance of the Group. Adjusted EBIT is a measure of the underlying profitability of the Group.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">A reconciliation is given on the face of the Consolidated Income Statement.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted EBIT growth</span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Year-on-year percentage increase in adjusted EBIT.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted results allow for the comparison of results year-on-year without the potentially distorting effects of significant one-off items or items which do not relate to the underlying performance of the Group. Adjusted EBIT growth is a measure of the movement in the underlying profitability of the Group.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Consistent with definition given.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted EBIT margin</span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">No direct equivalent</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted EBIT as a percentage of revenue.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted results allow for the comparison of results year-on-year without the potentially distorting effects of significant one-off items or items which do not relate to the underlying performance of the Group. Adjusted EBIT margin is a measure of the underlying profitability of the Group.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Consistent with definition given.</span></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="ub" style="width:99">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted EPS</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
</td>
<td class="ua" style="width:61">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">EPS</span></p>
</td>
<td class="tz" style="width:307">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted profit after tax divided by the weighted average number of ordinary shares. Weighted average number of ordinary shares are the same as those used in the Group's EPS calculation.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted results allow for the comparison of results year-on-year without the potentially distorting effects of significant one-off items or items which do not relate to the underlying performance of the Group. Adjusted EPS is a measure of the underlying earnings per share for the Group.</span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">Adjusted diluted EPS growth is a performance condition for LTIP vesting.</span></p>
<p class="u"><span class="aqa"> </span></p>

<td class="ty" style="width:137">
<p class="a"><span class="aqa">See note 11 of the notes to the Interim Report.</span></p>
